name: benzoic acid, 4-(dodecyloxy)-
Reason: The target compound is a dodecyloxy-substituted benzoic acid. The parent compound benzoic acid has a melting point of 122 °C. The dodecyloxy substituent, being a long alkyl chain, would typically lower the melting point due to introducing a degree of flexibility and disrupting the crystal lattice of the aromatic carboxylic acid. However, the sheer length of this chain (12 carbons) can enable van der Waals interactions that slightly counteract this effect. A rough estimate for the effect of each additional methylene group past the normal alkyl chain length for fatty acids (which usually contain up to about 10 carbons and increase melting points) on the melting point is about -2 to -5 °C per methylene group. Given there are two extra methylene groups in comparison to a decanoate (which would be expected to have a higher melting point due to better packing), this would give a range of -4 to -10 °C reduction from where the melting point might be without these two additional methylene groups.
